stream_context.summary: Kaze integrates a new low-level profiler, optimises Course 13 and imports Biobak’s updated Oily Boily Bay assets while chatting about technical bottlenecks, precision upgrades, and impending fatherhood.

development_findings.summary: A new dual trace/profiler by Sauron reveals that ~76 % of each frame is spent in an idle loop, exposing memory-latency bottlenecks and an RSP bottleneck.
development_findings.quote: Funny thing about RTYI, 25 out of 33 ms are spent on a while 1 loop… around 76 % of the entire game is just the game doing nothing at all.

development_findings.summary: Creating the large slide in Course 13 originally crashed the game because the collider crossed many spatial cells, exhausting surface-node memory; Kaze rewrote the allocator and gained ~400 µs CPU time.
development_findings.quote: When I first made this slide I ran out of memory… I did the whole memory allocation thing… and because of that we gained 400 microseconds of computing time.

development_findings.summary: To speed up trigonometric math Kaze replaced Mario 64’s lookup tables with polynomials, which also raised directional precision from 4 096 to 65 536 angles.
development_findings.quote: I had to switch to a polynomial… it increased the accuracy a lot as well.

development_findings.summary: Course 13 slide difficulty is reduced by scaling the geometry and adjusting camera considerations rather than tilting the camera programmatically.
Biobak’s new models/textures for Oily Boily Bay cut materials, bones and triangles, allowing the level to hit 30 FPS on console.
development_findings.quote: Dang, I think we can get Oily Boily Bay at 30 FPS now.

development_findings.summary: Fast64 auto-chooses unsuitable texture formats; Kaze manually switches certain assets from CI to RGBA to avoid colour and fog issues.
Ongoing plan to transition assets to F3DEX3 means abandoning scaled normals tricks and further simplifying materials.
Discovery that the Wiggler path code skipped waypoints if coordinates exceeded a threshold; fixing a ‘>200’ logic error stabilised its movement.
development_findings.quote: Now we fixed it… that’s why the path was so buggy at first.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expects his first child, Raina, and is on a two-month paternity leave, yet plans to spend the time ‘optimising the operating system on my N64’.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I'm still on two months of paternity leave. I'm gonna spend that time trying to optimise the operating system on my N64.

context_findings.summary: He recently moved out of Germany, criticises German bureaucracy and potential wealth tax, and praises Canada’s immigration process.
context_findings.quote: Living in Germany sucks. I'm so glad I moved out.

context_findings.summary: Shows excitement and relief when profiler and asset optimisations work, but expresses frustration with texture combiner quirks and emulator load times.

biobak.summary: Provides a large batch of revised assets (womps, tox boxes, wiggler faces, janitor/builder Koopas, glass, slopes) with fewer materials and bones, directly boosting performance.
biobak.quote: Goal new design and one fewer material… ten fewer bones total across all of the womps.

biobak.summary: Suggests and oversees an online colour-guessing quiz mid-stream, illustrating informal but responsive collaboration.

zeina.summary: Working on new overworld entrance models; Kaze previews static images and mentions Zeina taking initiative.
zeina.quote: Zeina is making a bunch of 3D models and stuff… saying ‘I wanted to give making the new overworld a try’.

key_stories.title: Profiler Revelation
key_stories.summary: Integrating Sauron’s new profiler immediately exposed that most frame time is wasted on idle loops and memory waits, re-orienting optimisation priorities.
key_stories.challenge: Previous tooling gave limited visibility into thread scheduling and hardware stalls.
key_stories.process: Kaze built the profiler into the ROM, limited FPS to read timelines, and analysed RDP/RSP/CPU graphs live.
key_stories.outcome: Identified memory latency and RSP as prime bottlenecks; opens path for scheduler and DMA tweaks.
key_stories.key_quote: This thing is actually amazing… the RDP runs just a little bit longer than the GFX right now, which shouldn’t be the case.

key_stories.title: The Slide That Broke Memory
key_stories.summary: A grand slide for Course 13 exceeded surface-node memory, crashing the game until Kaze rewrote the allocator.
key_stories.challenge: Slide collision crossed many 64×64 spatial cells, doubling node allocations.
key_stories.process: Implemented dynamic allocation scheme (documented in recent ‘Kaze Clips’ video).
key_stories.outcome: 400 µs CPU saved, slide restored; later scaled geometry to lower difficulty.
key_stories.key_quote: I ran out of memory… we gained 400 microseconds of computing time.

key_stories.title: Precision Upgrade via Polynomials
key_stories.summary: Switching sine/cos/atan from tables to polynomials delivered speed gains and 8× directional precision.
key_stories.challenge: Lookup tables were slow and coarse-grained.
key_stories.process: Derived polynomial approximations; replaced in engine.
key_stories.outcome: Controls now use 65 536 discrete angles; side-effect is older speedrun setups break.
key_stories.key_quote: I didn’t do it for accuracy, I did it for speed, but it increased the accuracy a lot as well.
